NewsLines.HeadLine: UPDATE 3-Israel, Palestinians meet on siege, no breakthrough

NewsLine.NewsLineText: MIDEAST (UPDATE 3, PICTURE):UPDATE 3-Israel, Palestinians meet on siege, no breakthrough

body.p: (Releads with talks, Erekat in compound, Arafat demands)
By Wafa Amr

RAMALLAH, West Bank, Sept 23 (Reuters) - Israeli and Palestinian officials held their first talks on Monday since the army imposed a siege on Yasser Arafat's West Bank headquarters, but failed to end the four-day-old standoff.

After the talks, the Israeli army briefly opened its tight security cordon around Arafat's devastated presidential complex in Ramallah to let chief Palestinian negotiator Saeb Erekat in to brief the Palestinian leader on the meeting.

Erekat said Israeli officials had refused to present him with a list of suspected militants they say are holed up with Arafat and should give themselves up, and demanded Arafat draw up a roster of all those in the compound, identifying militants.
"Arafat rejected the Israeli proposal," Erekat told Reuters.
Another Palestinian official said Arafat had demanded talks on political issues as well as military matters with Israel. Arafat also said he wanted the talks to be attended by U.S. representatives.

The failure of the talks dealt a new blow to hopes that the siege would end quickly and represented a further setback to international efforts to end two years of violence since the Palestinians rose up against Israeli occupation.

Israeli and Palestinian officials remained entrenched in the positions they have taken since Israeli tanks began the siege last Thursday in response to two suicide bombings that killed seven people in Israel, ending a six-week lull in such attacks.
"I will be here until all the wanted people leave," a senior Israeli military commander told reporters.

Mohammed Dahlan, Arafat's security adviser, retorted: "If Israel believes we will hand over any Palestinian or accept their deportation to Jericho or Gaza or anywhere else, it is wrong. We will not give Israel a way out to save face."
DIPLOMATIC EFFORTS FAIL

Efforts to launch a diplomatic initiative also floundered. Senior Israeli security sources said Israel did not give European Union special representative Miguel Angel Moratinos permission to enter Arafat's compound for talks.

European and U.S. officials have criticised the siege ahead of a United Nations Security Council debate on the crisis due later on Monday. The United States said on Sunday the Israeli operation was "not helpful".
Soon afterwards, the army stopped its demolition work at the compound, where it has reduced most of the structures to rubble and confined Arafat and more than 200 others to one building.
Washington wants to avert a surge in two years of Israeli-Palestinian violence which could complicate its plans for a possible attack on Iraq and further dim peace hopes.
The Palestinians, and some Israeli newspapers, say the real aim of the operation codenamed "A Matter of Time" is to oust or exile the Palestinian leader. Israel denies this.

Troops stood guard in the compound on Monday. Two tanks pointed their barrels at Arafat's building but the bulldozers which levelled most of the compound were no longer there and barbed wire surrounded the complex.
Thousands of Palestinians staged a second day of protests in the Gaza Strip, the West Bank cities of Bethlehem, Tulkarm and Qalqilya, and in East Jerusalem.

"We are all Yasser Arafat," protesters chanted in Gaza City, where some fired rifles into the air and vowed to step up attacks against Israel, highlighting Israeli concerns that the siege had boosted Arafat's support among ordinary Palestinians.
The protest in Bethlehem was followed by confrontations near Rachel's Tomb, a holy site for both sides, where about 200 students threw stones at Israeli soldiers.
Israeli forces shot dead four protesters during demonstrations on Sunday, the first outpouring of public sympathy for Arafat since the siege began.

Some Israeli newspapers question Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's decision to besiege Arafat's compound rather than try to rein in the Islamic militant group Hamas which has led the suicide bombing campaign.

Haaretz newspaper said the government's explanations for the siege were unconvincing. The Maariv newspaper said Arafat had been under more pressure from his own people last week, but the siege had won him a new wave of popular sympathy.
"The rebellion against Arafat which was gathering momentum over the past few weeks was suppressed and put down, at least temporarily, by Israel's bulldozers," Maariv commentator Ben Caspit said.
